title: 111_hr1191
content: The "Safe Drug Disposal Act of 2009" is also known as the "State Take-Back Disposal Programs" under the Controlled Substances Act. This section establishes state programs for the safe disposal of drugs. The Attorney General must create regulations within a year to allow individuals to dispose of controlled substances through State programs. These programs include 5 model State programs and allow States to create alternative disposal programs. The Attorney General must create regulations for State programs to dispose of controlled substances. Programs must require State legislation, protect public safety, allow disposal by non-law enforcement, use environmentally friendly practices, and be cost-effective. The regulations for State programs to dispose of controlled substances must be cost-effective, include convenient take-back options, and not restrict funding. Additionally, the program may apply to other drugs and biological products as well. The term 'care taker' is defined in this section. The term 'care taker' is defined as a person responsible for individuals or animals, including provision of controlled substances. The Comptroller General of the United States will collect data on State take-back disposal programs and submit findings to Congress every 4 years. The Comprehensive Drug Abuse Prevention and Control Act of 1970 is amended to include a new section after section 311. The Comprehensive Drug Abuse Prevention and Control Act of 1970 is amended to include a new section after section 311, which addresses state take-back disposal programs and prohibits labeling recommendations to dispose of drugs and biological products by flushing. The Comprehensive Drug Abuse Prevention and Control Act of 1970 is amended to prohibit labeling recommendations to dispose of drugs and biological products by flushing down the toilet. The Comprehensive Drug Abuse Prevention and Control Act of 1970 is amended to prohibit labeling recommendations to dispose of drugs and biological products by flushing down the toilet. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will review labeling of drugs already on the market for disposal instructions involving wastewater treatment systems. The Comprehensive Drug Abuse Prevention and Control Act of 1970 is amended to prohibit labeling recommendations to dispose of drugs and biological products by flushing down the toilet. Any violation of this order results in the product being deemed misbranded. The effective date for this order is within 1 year of the enactment of the Act. The terms "drug" and "labeling" are defined in section 201 of the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act.
